elements.content: On the basis of the bifunctional 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic acid (H2BTA), four three-dimensional (3D) Pb­(II)/Zn­(II) coordination polymers (CPs), {[Zn­(BTA)]­·1.5­(DOA)} n (1), [Zn­(BTA)] n (2), [Pb­(BTA)] n (3), and [Pb­(BTA)] n (4), have been synthesized (DOA = dioxane). Structural analyses reveal that two Zn­(II)-based complexes are 3D (4,4)-c pts pseudo-supramolecular isomers for 1 and 2, and two Pb­(II)-based complexes are supramolecular isomers with a 3D (4,5,6)-c net for 3 and a 3D 6-c pcu net for 4, respectively. Furthermore, the gas adsorption behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 for N2, CO2, and CH4 have been studied in detail at varying temperatures, and the results showed that the adsorption capacities to CO2 at 273 K and 1 bar are stronger than those of other gases. Meanwhile, the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 was evaluated by the usage of the ideal adsorbed solution theory, whose selectivity exceeded those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. In addition, the fluorescent measurements showed that 1–4 present high sensitivity and selectivity for Fe3+/Cr2O7 2– ions. And the possible fluorescence sensing mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions was also examined.

Structural analyses reveal that two Zn(II)-based complexes are 3D (4,4)-c pts pseudo-supramolecular isomers for 1 and 2, and two Pb(II)-based complexes are supramolecular isomers with a 3D (4,5,6)-c net for 3 and a 3D 6-c pcu net for 4, respectively. Furthermore, the gas adsorption behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 for N2, CO2, and CH4 have been studied in detail at varying temperatures, and the results showed that the adsorption capacities to CO2 at 273 K and 1 bar are stronger than those of other gases. Meanwhile, the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 was evaluated by the usage of the ideal adsorbed solution theory, whose selectivity exceeded those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. In addition, the fluorescent measurements showed that 1-4 present high sensitivity and selectivity for Fe3+/Cr2O7 2- ions. And the possible fluorescence sensing mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions was also examined.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) have become one of the research hotspots in the past two decades, which possess some particular characteristics such as versatile topologies, intriguing networks, and latent applications in gas sorption, fluorescence and sensing, and so on. With the development of industry and the progress of human society, industrial wastes and the inadvertent release of heavy metal ions pose a great threat to the human living environment. Fe3+ ions play a crucial role in many physiological processes including oxygen transport and storage. But excessive Fe3+ ions in a living cell pose huge damage to people’s health by incorporating with nucleic acids and proteins. Furthermore, some environmental problems related to sensing for heavy metal ions have inspired us to conduct the corresponding studies. At present, although there are many methods of detection of heavy metal ions, the disadvantages of being high cost and time-consuming, and requiring sophisticated devices limit their extensive application in the sensing of Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions. Thus, there is a very urgent need to develop a rapid and selective detection method for heavy metal ions (Fe3+/Cr2O7 2– ions) and to synthesize new functional materials as heavy metal ion sensors. Recently, CPs have been regarded as one of the most promising candidates for fluorescent probes, because of their high sensitivity, short response time, and easy portability and visualization. Furthermore, CPs have a large surface area, adjustable pore size, and easily modified function groups, which gives them greater potential applications in gas adsorption/separation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) have become one of the research hotspots in the past two decades, which possess some particular characteristics such as versatile topologies, intriguing networks, and latent applications in gas sorption, fluorescence and sensing, and so on. With the development of industry and the progress of human society, industrial wastes and the inadvertent release of heavy metal ions pose a great threat to the human living environment. Fe3+ ions play a crucial role in many physiological processes including oxygen transport and storage. But excessive Fe3+ ions in a living cell pose huge damage to people's health by incorporating with nucleic acids and proteins. Furthermore, some environmental problems related to sensing for heavy metal ions have inspired us to conduct the corresponding studies. At present, although there are many methods of detection of heavy metal ions, the disadvantages of being high cost and time-consuming, and requiring sophisticated devices limit their extensive application in the sensing of Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions. Thus, there is a very urgent need to develop a rapid and selective detection method for heavy metal ions (Fe3+/Cr2O7 2- ions) and to synthesize new functional materials as heavy metal ion sensors. Recently, CPs have been regarded as one of the most promising candidates for fluorescent probes, because of their high sensitivity, short response time, and easy portability and visualization. Furthermore, CPs have a large surface area, adjustable pore size, and easily modified function groups, which gives them greater potential applications in gas adsorption/separation.

elements.content: It is well-known that the potential applications of CPs largely depend on their structural characteristics. Because CPs’ syntheses are affected by many factors including organic ligands, metal ions, pH, solvent systems, temperature, and so on, it is a huge challenge to synthesize target CPs. Of all these conditions, the organic ligand is vital because physical properties of ligands directly affect the frameworks and properties of CPs. Meanwhile, it is also important that metal ions with d10 configuration are used to synthesize CPs with porous frameworks and excellent fluorescence properties.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that the potential applications of CPs largely depend on their structural characteristics. Because CPs' syntheses are affected by many factors including organic ligands, metal ions, pH, solvent systems, temperature, and so on, it is a huge challenge to synthesize target CPs. Of all these conditions, the organic ligand is vital because physical properties of ligands directly affect the frameworks and properties of CPs. Meanwhile, it is also important that metal ions with d10 configuration are used to synthesize CPs with porous frameworks and excellent fluorescence properties.

elements.content: Inspired by the aforementioned aspects, the 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic acid (H2BTA) is chosen in this work to construct the title CPs based on the following advantages: (i) the H2BTA ligand possesses various coordination modes and versatile coordination sites, which help construct multiporous CPs; (ii) it has a rigid skeleton, which is conducive to the construction of stable fluorescence CPs; (iii) the bis­(imidazole) groups can offer variable configurations to supply the coordinated requirements of metal centers. Hence, H2BTA based CPs might be excellent fluorescent sensors and porous materials, according to HSAB theory. Here, the reaction of the H2BTA ligand with Zn­(II) pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and Pb­(II) supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) has been designed and complexes were synthesized through adjusting the reacting solvents, namely, {[Zn­(BTA)]­·1.5­(DOA)} n (1), [Zn­(BTA)] n (2), [Pb­(BTA)] n (3), and [Pb­(BTA)] n (4). The fluorescence sensing of complexes 1–4 for different cations and anions was investigated. Meanwhile, the gas adsorption behaviors of 1 and 2 were also carried out. Moreover, we have discussed the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 and the mechanisms of the CPs’ fluorescent quenching effect.

Hence, H2BTA based CPs might be excellent fluorescent sensors and porous materials, according to HSAB theory. Here, the reaction of the H2BTA ligand with Zn(II) pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and Pb(II) supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) has been designed and complexes were synthesized through adjusting the reacting solvents, namely, {[Zn(BTA)]⋅1.5(DOA)} n  (1), [Zn(BTA)] n  (2), [Pb(BTA)] n  (3), and [Pb(BTA)] n  (4). The fluorescence sensing of complexes 1-4 for different cations and anions was investigated. Meanwhile, the gas adsorption behaviors of 1 and 2 were also carried out. Moreover, we have discussed the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 and the mechanisms of the CPs' fluorescent quenching effect.

elements.content: All reagents were commercially purchased and used directly. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were measured by a ZCTA analyzer from ambient temperature to 800 °C at a raising rate of 10 °C min–1 under nitrogen flow. Infrared (IR) spectra of the title CPs were obtained from KBr pellets on a spectrometer of FTIR-8400S from 600 to 4000 cm–1. PXRD patterns of CPs were measured on a diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-2500 PC) with Mo-Kα radiation at ambient temperature (2θ = 5–50°). Elemental analyses (H, C, N) were performed by using a Vario MACRO analyzer. Fluorescence experiments were carried out on a spectrophotometer (F-4600 FL) at 25 °C. The sorption behaviors for different gases were assessed using an ASAP-2020 analyzer. ICP measurements were performed by a (thermofisher) iCAP Qc ICP-MS emission spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were commercially purchased and used directly. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were measured by a ZCTA analyzer from ambient temperature to 800 °C at a raising rate of 10 °C min-1 under nitrogen flow. Infrared (IR) spectra of the title CPs were obtained from KBr pellets on a spectrometer of FTIR-8400S from 600 to 4000 cm-1. PXRD patterns of CPs were measured on a diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-2500 PC) with Mo-Kα radiation at ambient temperature (2θ = 5-50°). Elemental analyses (H, C, N) were performed by using a Vario MACRO analyzer. Fluorescence experiments were carried out on a spectrophotometer (F-4600 FL) at 25 °C. The sorption behaviors for different gases were assessed using an ASAP-2020 analyzer. ICP measurements were performed by a (thermofisher) iCAP Qc ICP-MS emission spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of H2BTA (1.19 mg, 0.004 mmol) and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.19 mg, 0.004 mmol) was dissolved in a mixed solution of dioxane (DOA) and water (1 mL, v:v = 1:1). The mixed solution was adjusted to pH = 4.0 with tetrafluoroboric acid, transferred to a glass tube, heated at 130 °C for a constant temperature reaction of 72 h, and then cooled gradually to ambient temperature. Finally, colorless and thin block crystals were collected. Anal. Calcd for C20H20N4O7Zn: C 48.65, H 4.08, N 11.35 (%). Found: C 48.27, H 4.19, N 11.19 (%). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3125 (m), 2351 (m), 1708 (vs), 1631 (s), 1523 (s), 1419 (m), 1342 (s), 1242 (s), 1074 (s), 835 (vs), 776 (w), 655 (s).

elements.content: X-ray crystallography data for compounds 1–4 were collected using a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer at 100/150/273/100 K with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were carried out. The structures of CPs were saved by direct methods using SHELXTL-2016 package with full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2. Crystal data and refinements for 1–4 were summarized in Table S1, and selected bond angles and separations are listed in Tables S2–S5. The CCDC numbers are 1852351 (1), 1852353 (2), 1852352 (3), and 1852350 (4), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallography data for compounds 1-4 were collected using a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer at 100/150/273/100 K with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were carried out. The structures of CPs were saved by direct methods using SHELXTL-2016 package with full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2. Crystal data and refinements for 1-4 were summarized in Table S1, and selected bond angles and separations are listed in Tables S2-S5. The CCDC numbers are 1852351 (1), 1852353 (2), 1852352 (3), and 1852350 (4), respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that compounds 1 and 2 are 3D pseudo-supramolecular isomers, and crystallize in the triclinic system P1̅ space group. The difference between them is only one and half lattice DOA molecules, for which the possible reasons are attributed to the difference in the kinetic radius of the solvents and the porosity of complexes 1 (44.3%) and 2 (30.6%), as well as the 1D channel size of 1 (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å) and 2 (13.390 Å × 10.617 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of {[Zn(BTA)]⋅1.5(DOA)} n  (1) and [Zn(BTA)] n  (2).

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that compounds 1 and 2 are 3D pseudo-supramolecular isomers, and crystallize in the triclinic system P1̅ space group. The difference between them is only one and half lattice DOA molecules, for which the possible reasons are attributed to the difference in the kinetic radius of the solvents and the porosity of complexes 1 (44.3%) and 2 (30.6%), as well as the 1D channel size of 1 (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å) and 2 (13.390 Å × 10.617 Å).

elements.content: So the crystal structure of 1 is only described in detail. For complex 2, the detailed structural description can be found in the Supporting Information. There are one crystallographically independent ZnII ion, two halves of BTA2– linkers, and one and half DOA molecules in the asymmetric unit (a). Each ZnII ion is surrounded by two O-atoms (O1 and O3) and two N-atoms (N2A and N4B) from four BTA2– ligands, and presents a distorted {ZnO2N2} tetrahedron geometry with τ4 = 0.88. And the O–Zn bond separations are 1.945(5) Å and 1.957(2) Å, and the N–Zn bond separations are 2.009(2) Å and 2.028(2) Å.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with P21 /c space group. There are one PbII ion and two halves of BTA2– ligands in the asymmetric unit. As can be seen from a, the central PbII ion is surrounded by three O atoms from the carboxyl of three BTA2– ligands (O1A, O3C, and O4B) and two N atoms from imidazolyl groups (N1 and N3), and exhibits a distorted {PbO3N2} tetragonal pyramid geometry. And the Pb–O/N separations are between 2.402(3) Å and 2.700(3) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Pb(BTA)] n  (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with P21 /c space group. There are one PbII ion and two halves of BTA2- ligands in the asymmetric unit. As can be seen from a, the central PbII ion is surrounded by three O atoms from the carboxyl of three BTA2- ligands (O1A, O3C, and O4B) and two N atoms from imidazolyl groups (N1 and N3), and exhibits a distorted {PbO3N2} tetragonal pyramid geometry. And the Pb-O/N separations are between 2.402(3) Å and 2.700(3) Å.

elements.content: By changing the solvents, complex 4, which is supramolecular isomer with complex 3, was synthesized here, and crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of a half of crystallographically independent PbII ions and half BTA2– linkers (a). The PbII ion is C 2-symmetric and surrounded by two N-atoms and four O-atoms from six distinct BTA2– ligands, and exhibits a distorted {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry. The N–Pb bond separations are 2.619(6) Å, and the O–Pb bond separations are 2.409(6) Å and 2.731(6) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Pb(BTA)] n  (4)

By changing the solvents, complex 4, which is supramolecular isomer with complex 3, was synthesized here, and crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of a half of crystallographically independent PbII ions and half BTA2- linkers (a). The PbII ion is C 2-symmetric and surrounded by two N-atoms and four O-atoms from six distinct BTA2- ligands, and exhibits a distorted {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry. The N-Pb bond separations are 2.619(6) Å, and the O-Pb bond separations are 2.409(6) Å and 2.731(6) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Different from the coordination modes in 1–3, the two carboxyl of the BTA2– ligand adopt a bridging μ2-η1:η1 type in 4. And the dihedral angle between phenyl ring and imidazolyl rings is 41.70°. In addition, the carboxylate groups of the BTA2‑ ligands connect with PbII ions to form 1D {Pb­(COO)2} n chains (c) and among them the nearest Pb···Pb distance is 4.637(3) Å, which are further linked by the μ6-BTA2‑ linkers to obtain a 3D network (b). By topology, when both the BTA2– ligands and the PbII ions serve as 6-c nodes, the whole network of 4 can be seen as a 3D 6-c pcu net topology with the point symbol of (42.63) (d).
elements.clean_text: Different from the coordination modes in 1-3, the two carboxyl of the BTA2- ligand adopt a bridging μ2-η1:η1 type in 4. And the dihedral angle between phenyl ring and imidazolyl rings is 41.70°. In addition, the carboxylate groups of the BTA2- ligands connect with PbII ions to form 1D {Pb(COO)2} n  chains (c) and among them the nearest Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb distance is 4.637(3) Å, which are further linked by the μ6-BTA2- linkers to obtain a 3D network (b). By topology, when both the BTA2- ligands and the PbII ions serve as 6-c nodes, the whole network of 4 can be seen as a 3D 6-c pcu net topology with the point symbol of (42.63) (d).

elements.content: From the viewpoint of syntheses, pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) were obtained under same conditions except for using different solvents. As exhibited in and , the H2BTA linkers have two sorts of different coordination modes in the construction of 1–4. When the carboxylate groups of the H2BTA ligands are omitted, the ligands can be seen as 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­benzene (bib); conversely, when the imidazolyl groups are omitted, the terephthalic acid (H2TPA) was left. Thus, to simplify the nets and help the structural comparisons of CPs, the M-bib and M-TPA motifs are discussed in the following. In view of the aforementioned aspects and , the bib ligands adopt trans-configuration in the title CPs (Figures S1–S4), and thus we compared basically the M-TPA motifs. In 1 and 2, the carboxyl in the TPA2– ligands adopt monodentate μ1-η1 shape to link ZnII ions forming 1D [Zn­(TPA)] n chains (Figures S5 and S6). As for 3, the carboxyl of the BTA2– ligands adopt two kinds of bridging coordination modes (μ1-η1, Mode I and μ2-η1:η1, Mode II) to link the PbII ions obtaining a 3D [Pb­(TPA)] n net (Figure S7). For 4, the bridging (μ2-η1:η1, Mode II) carboxyl connect with PbII ions to obtain 1D {Pb­(COO)2}n chains, which are extended into 2D [Pb­(TPA)] n sheets by the H2BTA ligands (Figure S8). So the huge differences among the title CPs can mainly be attributed to solvent effect. As a result, the coordination environments of central ions present a {ZnO2N2} tetrahedron geometry for 1 and 2, a {PbO3N2} tetragonal pyramid geometry for 3 and a {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry for 4, respectively. Finally, with the help of 1D [M­(bib)] n chains, those M-TPA motifs are further expanded into pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) with a 3D (4,4)-c pts net topology, and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) with a 3D (4,5,6)-c net topology for 3 and a 3D 6-c pcu net topology for 4, respectively. By the structural comparisons in detail, it is obvious that the solvent exerts a crucial effect on the construction of pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparisons

From the viewpoint of syntheses, pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) were obtained under same conditions except for using different solvents. As exhibited in  and , the H2BTA linkers have two sorts of different coordination modes in the construction of 1-4. When the carboxylate groups of the H2BTA ligands are omitted, the ligands can be seen as 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (bib); conversely, when the imidazolyl groups are omitted, the terephthalic acid (H2TPA) was left. Thus, to simplify the nets and help the structural comparisons of CPs, the M-bib and M-TPA motifs are discussed in the following. In view of the aforementioned aspects and , the bib ligands adopt trans-configuration in the title CPs (Figures S1-S4), and thus we compared basically the M-TPA motifs. In 1 and 2, the carboxyl in the TPA2- ligands adopt monodentate μ1-η1 shape to link ZnII ions forming 1D [Zn(TPA)] n  chains (Figures S5 and S6). As for 3, the carboxyl of the BTA2- ligands adopt two kinds of bridging coordination modes (μ1-η1, Mode I and μ2-η1:η1, Mode II) to link the PbII ions obtaining a 3D [Pb(TPA)] n  net (Figure S7). For 4, the bridging (μ2-η1:η1, Mode II) carboxyl connect with PbII ions to obtain 1D {Pb(COO)2}n chains, which are extended into 2D [Pb(TPA)] n  sheets by the H2BTA ligands (Figure S8). So the huge differences among the title CPs can mainly be attributed to solvent effect. As a result, the coordination environments of central ions present a {ZnO2N2} tetrahedron geometry for 1 and 2, a {PbO3N2} tetragonal pyramid geometry for 3 and a {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry for 4, respectively. Finally, with the help of 1D [M(bib)] n  chains, those M-TPA motifs are further expanded into pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) with a 3D (4,4)-c pts net topology, and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4) with a 3D (4,5,6)-c net topology for 3 and a 3D 6-c pcu net topology for 4, respectively. By the structural comparisons in detail, it is obvious that the solvent exerts a crucial effect on the construction of pseudo-supramolecular isomers (1 and 2) and supramolecular isomers (3 and 4).

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the title compounds were checked at ambient temperature to verify the single phase of these CPs. As exhibited in Figure S9, the pivotal peak positions of the theoretical and experimental PXRD patterns are in accordance with one another, which shows that the title CPs are single phase. Thermogravimetric measurements of 1–4 were performed to assess the stability of CPs (Figure S10). As for 1, a 26.23% weight loss corresponds to one and a half lattice DOA molecules below 184 °C (calcd: 26.72%), and the framework begins to collapse above 350 °C. For complexes 2–4, their frameworks are stable before 350 °C for 2, 470 °C for 3, 490 °C for 4, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermal Analyses

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the title compounds were checked at ambient temperature to verify the single phase of these CPs. As exhibited in Figure S9, the pivotal peak positions of the theoretical and experimental PXRD patterns are in accordance with one another, which shows that the title CPs are single phase. Thermogravimetric measurements of 1-4 were performed to assess the stability of CPs (Figure S10). As for 1, a 26.23% weight loss corresponds to one and a half lattice DOA molecules below 184 °C (calcd: 26.72%), and the framework begins to collapse above 350 °C. For complexes 2-4, their frameworks are stable before 350 °C for 2, 470 °C for 3, 490 °C for 4, respectively.

elements.content: Taking into consideration the high porosity of complexes 1 and 2, their gas adsorption behaviors were studied. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were soaked in methanol for 72 h. The samples were filtrated and dried at 150 °C for 10 h under a vacuum to attain the activated samples, whose PXRD patterns are basically the same as the original ones, and this result showed that their structures are stable (Figure S9). As can be seen from , the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 2 present typical type-II adsorption behaviors at 77 K. The N2 isotherm curves have an abrupt slope in the range of 0.01 to 0.1 bar, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between the adsorbents on the surface as the increase of pressure from 0.01 to 0.1 bar. The maximum N2 uptake is 42.4 cm3 g–1 for 1 and 32.6 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 77 K and 1 bar, respectively. The BET surface area is 67.7 m2·g–1 for 1 and 56.6 m2·g–1 for 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorptions

Taking into consideration the high porosity of complexes 1 and 2, their gas adsorption behaviors were studied. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were soaked in methanol for 72 h. The samples were filtrated and dried at 150 °C for 10 h under a vacuum to attain the activated samples, whose PXRD patterns are basically the same as the original ones, and this result showed that their structures are stable (Figure S9). As can be seen from , the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 2 present typical type-II adsorption behaviors at 77 K. The N2 isotherm curves have an abrupt slope in the range of 0.01 to 0.1 bar, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between the adsorbents on the surface as the increase of pressure from 0.01 to 0.1 bar. The maximum N2 uptake is 42.4 cm3 g-1 for 1 and 32.6 cm3 g-1 for 2 at 77 K and 1 bar, respectively. The BET surface area is 67.7 m2⋅g-1 for 1 and 56.6 m2⋅g-1 for 2, respectively.

elements.content: N2, CO2, and CH4 adsorption and desorption isotherms of complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  N2, CO2, and CH4 adsorption and desorption isotherms of complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b).

elements.content: The adsorption behaviors of CPs 1 and 2 for CO2 and CH4 were also measured at low-pressure and varying temperatures. Compared with the N2 sorption isotherms, the sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 display slight hysteresis between adsorption and desorption curves, which indicated the interactions between host frameworks of CPs and adsorbates and allow CO2 to be stored at lower pressures but adsorbed at high pressures. At 1 bar, the CO2 uptakes are 62.1 cm3·g–1 (273 K) and 49.1 cm3·g–1 (298 K) for 1, 55.7 cm3·g–1 (273 K) and 43.0 cm3·g–1 (298 K) for 2, respectively. Compared with some famous zeolites’ structures and previously reported MOFs such as ZIF-78, etc., 1 and 2 have higher CO2 adsorption capacity and are approximately equal to those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. The CH4 uptakes are very low for CPs 1 and 2, which can be due to weaker interactions between the frameworks of 1 and 2 and CH4, and larger kinetic radius of CH4.

At 1 bar, the CO2 uptakes are 62.1 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K) and 49.1 cm3⋅g-1 (298 K) for 1, 55.7 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K) and 43.0 cm3⋅g-1 (298 K) for 2, respectively. Compared with some famous zeolites' structures and previously reported MOFs such as ZIF-78, etc., 1 and 2 have higher CO2 adsorption capacity and are approximately equal to those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. The CH4 uptakes are very low for CPs 1 and 2, which can be due to weaker interactions between the frameworks of 1 and 2 and CH4, and larger kinetic radius of CH4.

elements.content: To appraise the adsorption selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2–CH4 gas mixtures, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used. The adsorption selectivity is 11 (V:V, CO2/CH4 = 50:50) and 16 (V:V, CO2/CH4 = 5:95) for 1 at 1 bar and 298 K respectively (a), which exceeds those of some MOFs under same conditions such as JLU-Liu37 (3.8 and 3.8) and JLU-Liu38 (5.6 and 5.4). Similar to that of 1, the adsorption selectivity is 29 and 118 for 2 respectively (b), which go beyond those of some MOFs under same conditions, such as UTSA-16 (52.0 at equimolar, 298 K, and 1 bar) and MOF-177 (4.4 at equimolar, 298 K, and 1 bar).

elements.content: The solid-state fluorescence spectra of CPs 1–4 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure S11). The emission spectra of 1–4 all exhibited strong blue fluorescent emission peaks (λex = 280 nm) at 425 nm (1), 427.5 nm (2), 422.5 nm (3), 440 nm (4), respectively. Compared with the H2BTA ligand, the maximum emissions of CPs 1–4 are obviously red-shift, which may be due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Sensing

The solid-state fluorescence spectra of CPs 1-4 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure S11). The emission spectra of 1-4 all exhibited strong blue fluorescent emission peaks (λex = 280 nm) at 425 nm (1), 427.5 nm (2), 422.5 nm (3), 440 nm (4), respectively. Compared with the H2BTA ligand, the maximum emissions of CPs 1-4 are obviously red-shift, which may be due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

elements.content: The varying intensities of the emission peaks for 1–4 can greatly be attributed to the differences in the coordinated modes of H2BTA, the coordinated environments of metal ions, and solvent molecules in the frameworks. To further investigate fluorescence sensing of 1–4, different solvent molecules, including DMA, DMSO, DMF, MeCN, H2O, BuOH, and acetone, were chosen as the analytes. As shown in Figure S12, the suspension of 1@H2O displayed the strongest fluorescent intensity, while the suspension of 1@acetone exhibited the weakest emission. However, the suspensions of complexes 2–4 in DMF exhibited the strongest fluorescence intensity, and the emissions in acetone are similar to that of 1. Taking into consideration the fluorescent intensity of the suspension of 1@H2O and the practical application in the detection of ions, we selected 1 dispersed in H2O (1@H2O) and 2–4 in DMF (CPs@DMF) as a standard solution in the following fluorescence experiments.

To further investigate fluorescence sensing of 1-4, different solvent molecules, including DMA, DMSO, DMF, MeCN, H2O, BuOH, and acetone, were chosen as the analytes. As shown in Figure S12, the suspension of 1@H2O displayed the strongest fluorescent intensity, while the suspension of 1@acetone exhibited the weakest emission. However, the suspensions of complexes 2-4 in DMF exhibited the strongest fluorescence intensity, and the emissions in acetone are similar to that of 1. Taking into consideration the fluorescent intensity of the suspension of 1@H2O and the practical application in the detection of ions, we selected 1 dispersed in H2O (1@H2O) and 2-4 in DMF (CPs@DMF) as a standard solution in the following fluorescence experiments.

elements.content: To deeply explore the sensing sensitivity of 1–4 for metal ions, a 2 mg sample of the title CPs was separately dispersed in 2 mL of 0.01 mol·L–1 M­(NO3) n solution (M = Co2+, K+, Ag+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, Fe3+, and Cr3+). As shown in , the fluorescent intensities of M n+@CPs suspensions largely depend on the varying metal ions, while Fe3+ ions exhibited extremely significant fluorescence quenching effect for CPs.

As shown in , the fluorescent intensities of M n+@CPs suspensions largely depend on the varying metal ions, while Fe3+ ions exhibited extremely significant fluorescence quenching effect for CPs.

elements.content: To better test the fluorescent response of the title CPs to Fe3+ ions, the effect of Fe3+ concentration gradient on fluorescence intensities of the title CPs was also investigated (), which can be explained by the Stern–Volmer (SV) linear equation for 1 in the whole concentration and the SV exponential equations for 2–4 at higher concentration (). The SV plots of I 0/I vs the concentrations of Fe3+ ions were nearly linear (I 0/I = K s v[Fe3+] + 1) at low concentrations, in which I and I 0 are the fluorescent intensities after and before adding Fe3+ ions. The K s v values and the quenching rates are given in . Furthermore, as can be seen in , the fluorescence quenching effect gradually increased with the concentration addition of Fe3+ ions.

The SV plots of I 0/I vs the concentrations of Fe3+ ions were nearly linear (I 0/I = K s v[Fe3+] + 1) at low concentrations, in which I and I 0 are the fluorescent intensities after and before adding Fe3+ ions. The K s v values and the quenching rates are given in . Furthermore, as can be seen in , the fluorescence quenching effect gradually increased with the concentration addition of Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: In order to clarify the possible fluorescence sensing mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions, a series of experiments have been designed and carried out. First, after the samples of the title CPs were treated by immersion in different ionic solutions for one day, the pivotal peak positions of the treated and original PXRD patterns were similar to each other, and these results showed that the fluorescent decay is not caused by the decomposition of the CPs’ structures (Figure S9). Second, the suspensions of CPs@M after the fluorescence experiments were detected by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP), and no zinc or lead ions were detected in the suspension (Table S6 and Table S7), indicating that the fluorescence quenching was not due to ion exchange. Moreover, the UV–visible absorption spectra of the Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– solutions largely overlapped with the excitation spectra of 1–4 (Figure S13), which partly accounts for the mechanism of fluorescent quenching, and indicates that competitive absorption exists between Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2– ions and the frameworks of 1–4. Furthermore, the weak interactions between Fe3+/Cr2O7 2– ions and the frameworks of CPs may play a partial role. It is particularly worth mentioning that the carboxyl of ligands in complexes 3 and 4 adopt different coordination modes. In this way, compared with complex 4, complex 3 has uncoordinated oxygen atoms on the surface of the framework, so that the interactions between the frameworks of complex 3 and Cr3+ ions are stronger. As a result, the fluorescence quenching of Cr3+ ions for 3 is stronger.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Fluorescence Quenching

In order to clarify the possible fluorescence sensing mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions, a series of experiments have been designed and carried out. First, after the samples of the title CPs were treated by immersion in different ionic solutions for one day, the pivotal peak positions of the treated and original PXRD patterns were similar to each other, and these results showed that the fluorescent decay is not caused by the decomposition of the CPs' structures (Figure S9). Second, the suspensions of CPs@M after the fluorescence experiments were detected by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP), and no zinc or lead ions were detected in the suspension (Table S6 and Table S7), indicating that the fluorescence quenching was not due to ion exchange. Moreover, the UV-visible absorption spectra of the Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- solutions largely overlapped with the excitation spectra of 1-4 (Figure S13), which partly accounts for the mechanism of fluorescent quenching, and indicates that competitive absorption exists between Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2- ions and the frameworks of 1-4. Furthermore, the weak interactions between Fe3+/Cr2O7 2- ions and the frameworks of CPs may play a partial role. It is particularly worth mentioning that the carboxyl of ligands in complexes 3 and 4 adopt different coordination modes. In this way, compared with complex 4, complex 3 has uncoordinated oxygen atoms on the surface of the framework, so that the interactions between the frameworks of complex 3 and Cr3+ ions are stronger. As a result, the fluorescence quenching of Cr3+ ions for 3 is stronger.

elements.content: In summary, on the basis of the ligand of H2BTA, pseudo-supramolecular isomers and supramolecular isomers were designed and synthesized by adjusting the reacting solvents, whose structures are 3D (4,4)-connected pts net for complexes 1 and 2, a 3D (4,5,6)-connected net for 3, and a 3D 6-connected pcu net for 4. By structural comparisons among the title CPs in detail, the results revealed that the solvent exerts a profound influence on controlling the structures of CPs. Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments showed that 1 and 2 have stronger sorption capacities to CO2 than those of other gases at 273 K and 1 bar. Meanwhile, the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 was evaluated by using IAST, whose selectivity exceeded those of some MOFs under same conditions. Moreover, the fluorescent measurements showed that 1–4 present high selectivity and sensitivity for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions. And the possible fluorescence quenching mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions can be partly attributed to the competitive adsorption between Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions and the frameworks of 1–4. The results showed the title CPs are expected to be used for the fluorescence probe of heavy metal ions, while complexes 1 and 2 have potential applications in the separation and purification of CO2 in natural gas.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, on the basis of the ligand of H2BTA, pseudo-supramolecular isomers and supramolecular isomers were designed and synthesized by adjusting the reacting solvents, whose structures are 3D (4,4)-connected pts net for complexes 1 and 2, a 3D (4,5,6)-connected net for 3, and a 3D 6-connected pcu net for 4. By structural comparisons among the title CPs in detail, the results revealed that the solvent exerts a profound influence on controlling the structures of CPs. Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments showed that 1 and 2 have stronger sorption capacities to CO2 than those of other gases at 273 K and 1 bar. Meanwhile, the selectivity of 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 was evaluated by using IAST, whose selectivity exceeded those of some MOFs under same conditions. Moreover, the fluorescent measurements showed that 1-4 present high selectivity and sensitivity for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions. And the possible fluorescence quenching mechanism of CPs to Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions can be partly attributed to the competitive adsorption between Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions and the frameworks of 1-4. The results showed the title CPs are expected to be used for the fluorescence probe of heavy metal ions, while complexes 1 and 2 have potential applications in the separation and purification of CO2 in natural gas.

A mixture of H2BTA (1.19 mg, 0.004 mmol) and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.19 mg, 0.004 mmol) was dissolved in a mixed solution of dioxane (DOA) and water (1 mL, v:v = 1:1). The mixed solution was adjusted to pH = 4.0 with tetrafluoroboric acid, transferred to a glass tube, heated at 130 °C for a constant temperature reaction of 72 h, and then cooled gradually to ambient temperature. Finally, colorless and thin block crystals were collected. Anal. Calcd for C20H20N4O7Zn: C 48.65, H 4.08, N 11.35 (%). Found: C 48.27, H 4.19, N 11.19 (%). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3125 (m), 2351 (m), 1708 (vs), 1631 (s), 1523 (s), 1419 (m), 1342 (s), 1242 (s), 1074 (s), 835 (vs), 776 (w), 655 (s).

Preparation of [Zn­(BTA)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The synthetic method is similar to that of 1 except that N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) replaced DOA and no acid was added. Colorless and diamond-shaped crystals were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C14H8N4O4Zn: C 46.50, H 2.23, N 15.49 (%). Found: C 46.27, H 2.36, N 15.30 (%). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3120 (w), 3041 (w), 2358 (vs), 1616 (vs), 1516 (s), 1425 (s), 1355 (s), 1242 (m), 1118 (m), 1072 (vs), 979 (m), 945 (m), 833 (m), 765 (m), 646 (s).

Preparation of [Pb­(BTA)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The mixture of H2BTA (2.98 mg, 0.01 mmol), Pb­(NO3)2 (3.31 mg, 0.01 mmol), 2 mL of DMA, and 2 mL of DOA was added to 25 mL stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. After slowly cooling to 25 °C, colorless bulk crystals were achieved. Anal. Calcd for C14H8N4O4Pb: C 33.40, H 1.60, N 11.13 (%). Found: C 33.58, H 1.67, N 11.17 (%). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3130 (m), 3078 (w), 2362 (m), 1566 (m), 1504 (m), 1416 (m), 1365 (s), 1236 (w), 1118 (s), 1062 (vs), 972 (m), 925 (w), 831 (w), 792 (w), 646 (vs).

Preparation of [Pb­(BTA)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

The synthesis procedure of 4 is the same as that of 3 except that the solvents were replaced by 2 mL of ethanol and 0.1 mL of nitric acid (0.25 mol/L), and colorless and schistose crystals were attained. Anal. Calcd for C14H8N4O4Pb: C 33.40, H 1.60, N 11.13 (%). Found: C 33.47, H 1.67, N 11.21 (%). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3126 (w), 2362 (s), 1575 (vs), 1506 (s), 1413 (m), 1365 (vs), 1236 (w), 1110 (m), 1065 (vs), 972 (w), 923 (w), 829 (s), 651 (s).

cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that compounds 1 and 2 are 3D pseudo-supramolecular isomers, and crystallize in the triclinic system P1̅ space group. The difference between them is only one and half lattice DOA molecules, for which the possible reasons are attributed to the difference in the kinetic radius of the solvents and the porosity of complexes 1 (44.3%) and 2 (30.6%), as well as the 1D channel size of 1 (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å) and 2 (13.390 Å × 10.617 Å).

For 1, the BTA2– ligands adopt a monodentate bridging mode (Mode I, ) to connect ZnII ions forming 3D networks with a 1D channel (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å), which is filled by the lattice DOA molecules (b). The dihedral angles between imidazolyl rings and phenyl ring are 70.80° and 41.68° in the BTA2– ligand. After the removal of the solvent molecules, the porosity of 1 is 44.3% (480.3 Å3 out of 1084.9 Å3).

Structural Description of [Pb­(BTA)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

By changing the solvents, complex 4, which is supramolecular isomer with complex 3, was synthesized here, and crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of a half of crystallographically independent PbII ions and half BTA2– linkers (a). The PbII ion is C 2-symmetric and surrounded by two N-atoms and four O-atoms from six distinct BTA2– ligands, and exhibits a distorted {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry. The N–Pb bond separations are 2.619(6) Å, and the O–Pb bond separations are 2.409(6) Å and 2.731(6) Å, respectively.

X-ray Powder Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermal Analyses

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the title compounds were checked at ambient temperature to verify the single phase of these CPs. As exhibited in Figure S9, the pivotal peak positions of the theoretical and experimental PXRD patterns are in accordance with one another, which shows that the title CPs are single phase. Thermogravimetric measurements of 1–4 were performed to assess the stability of CPs (Figure S10). As for 1, a 26.23% weight loss corresponds to one and a half lattice DOA molecules below 184 °C (calcd: 26.72%), and the framework begins to collapse above 350 °C. For complexes 2–4, their frameworks are stable before 350 °C for 2, 470 °C for 3, 490 °C for 4, respectively.

Gas Adsorptions

Taking into consideration the high porosity of complexes 1 and 2, their gas adsorption behaviors were studied. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were soaked in methanol for 72 h. The samples were filtrated and dried at 150 °C for 10 h under a vacuum to attain the activated samples, whose PXRD patterns are basically the same as the original ones, and this result showed that their structures are stable (Figure S9). As can be seen from , the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 2 present typical type-II adsorption behaviors at 77 K. The N2 isotherm curves have an abrupt slope in the range of 0.01 to 0.1 bar, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between the adsorbents on the surface as the increase of pressure from 0.01 to 0.1 bar. The maximum N2 uptake is 42.4 cm3 g–1 for 1 and 32.6 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 77 K and 1 bar, respectively. The BET surface area is 67.7 m2·g–1 for 1 and 56.6 m2·g–1 for 2, respectively.

The adsorption behaviors of CPs 1 and 2 for CO2 and CH4 were also measured at low-pressure and varying temperatures. Compared with the N2 sorption isotherms, the sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 display slight hysteresis between adsorption and desorption curves, which indicated the interactions between host frameworks of CPs and adsorbates and allow CO2 to be stored at lower pressures but adsorbed at high pressures. At 1 bar, the CO2 uptakes are 62.1 cm3·g–1 (273 K) and 49.1 cm3·g–1 (298 K) for 1, 55.7 cm3·g–1 (273 K) and 43.0 cm3·g–1 (298 K) for 2, respectively. Compared with some famous zeolites’ structures and previously reported MOFs such as ZIF-78, etc., 1 and 2 have higher CO2 adsorption capacity and are approximately equal to those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. The CH4 uptakes are very low for CPs 1 and 2, which can be due to weaker interactions between the frameworks of 1 and 2 and CH4, and larger kinetic radius of CH4.

Fluorescent Sensing

The solid-state fluorescence spectra of CPs 1–4 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure S11). The emission spectra of 1–4 all exhibited strong blue fluorescent emission peaks (λex = 280 nm) at 425 nm (1), 427.5 nm (2), 422.5 nm (3), 440 nm (4), respectively. Compared with the H2BTA ligand, the maximum emissions of CPs 1–4 are obviously red-shift, which may be due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

Results and Discussion

Structural Description of {[Zn(BTA)]⋅1.5(DOA)} n  (1) and [Zn(BTA)] n  (2).

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that compounds 1 and 2 are 3D pseudo-supramolecular isomers, and crystallize in the triclinic system P1̅ space group. The difference between them is only one and half lattice DOA molecules, for which the possible reasons are attributed to the difference in the kinetic radius of the solvents and the porosity of complexes 1 (44.3%) and 2 (30.6%), as well as the 1D channel size of 1 (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å) and 2 (13.390 Å × 10.617 Å).

For 1, the BTA2- ligands adopt a monodentate bridging mode (Mode I, ) to connect ZnII ions forming 3D networks with a 1D channel (13.314 Å × 13.354 Å), which is filled by the lattice DOA molecules (b). The dihedral angles between imidazolyl rings and phenyl ring are 70.80° and 41.68° in the BTA2- ligand. After the removal of the solvent molecules, the porosity of 1 is 44.3% (480.3 Å3 out of 1084.9 Å3).

Structural Description of [Pb(BTA)] n  (4)

By changing the solvents, complex 4, which is supramolecular isomer with complex 3, was synthesized here, and crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of a half of crystallographically independent PbII ions and half BTA2- linkers (a). The PbII ion is C 2-symmetric and surrounded by two N-atoms and four O-atoms from six distinct BTA2- ligands, and exhibits a distorted {PbO4N2} octahedron geometry. The N-Pb bond separations are 2.619(6) Å, and the O-Pb bond separations are 2.409(6) Å and 2.731(6) Å, respectively.

X-ray Powder Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermal Analyses

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the title compounds were checked at ambient temperature to verify the single phase of these CPs. As exhibited in Figure S9, the pivotal peak positions of the theoretical and experimental PXRD patterns are in accordance with one another, which shows that the title CPs are single phase. Thermogravimetric measurements of 1-4 were performed to assess the stability of CPs (Figure S10). As for 1, a 26.23% weight loss corresponds to one and a half lattice DOA molecules below 184 °C (calcd: 26.72%), and the framework begins to collapse above 350 °C. For complexes 2-4, their frameworks are stable before 350 °C for 2, 470 °C for 3, 490 °C for 4, respectively.

Gas Adsorptions

Taking into consideration the high porosity of complexes 1 and 2, their gas adsorption behaviors were studied. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were soaked in methanol for 72 h. The samples were filtrated and dried at 150 °C for 10 h under a vacuum to attain the activated samples, whose PXRD patterns are basically the same as the original ones, and this result showed that their structures are stable (Figure S9). As can be seen from , the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 2 present typical type-II adsorption behaviors at 77 K. The N2 isotherm curves have an abrupt slope in the range of 0.01 to 0.1 bar, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between the adsorbents on the surface as the increase of pressure from 0.01 to 0.1 bar. The maximum N2 uptake is 42.4 cm3 g-1 for 1 and 32.6 cm3 g-1 for 2 at 77 K and 1 bar, respectively. The BET surface area is 67.7 m2⋅g-1 for 1 and 56.6 m2⋅g-1 for 2, respectively.

The adsorption behaviors of CPs 1 and 2 for CO2 and CH4 were also measured at low-pressure and varying temperatures. Compared with the N2 sorption isotherms, the sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 display slight hysteresis between adsorption and desorption curves, which indicated the interactions between host frameworks of CPs and adsorbates and allow CO2 to be stored at lower pressures but adsorbed at high pressures. At 1 bar, the CO2 uptakes are 62.1 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K) and 49.1 cm3⋅g-1 (298 K) for 1, 55.7 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K) and 43.0 cm3⋅g-1 (298 K) for 2, respectively. Compared with some famous zeolites' structures and previously reported MOFs such as ZIF-78, etc., 1 and 2 have higher CO2 adsorption capacity and are approximately equal to those of reported MOFs under similar conditions. The CH4 uptakes are very low for CPs 1 and 2, which can be due to weaker interactions between the frameworks of 1 and 2 and CH4, and larger kinetic radius of CH4. 

Fluorescent Sensing

The solid-state fluorescence spectra of CPs 1-4 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure S11). The emission spectra of 1-4 all exhibited strong blue fluorescent emission peaks (λex = 280 nm) at 425 nm (1), 427.5 nm (2), 422.5 nm (3), 440 nm (4), respectively. Compared with the H2BTA ligand, the maximum emissions of CPs 1-4 are obviously red-shift, which may be due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

metadata.title:
Syntheses, Gas Adsorption, and Sensing Properties
of Solvent-Controlled Zn(II) Pseudo-Supramolecular Isomers and Pb(II) Supramolecular Isomers
